title: Oil Price Crash Has 'Cost 65,000 UK Jobs'
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Sep 9, 2015, 11:05 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 25 mins Oil Price Crash Has 'Cost 65,000 UK Jobs' By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 22 minutes ago View Photo 

A crisis summit is reportedly due to discuss what can be done to support the North Sea oil industry, as a report finds 65,000 UK jobs have been lost since the collapse in prices. 
The job loss calculation was revealed in an annual economic report by trade association Oil & Gas UK. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) said it believed 6,000 front-line roles had gone, along with 30,000 in the direct industry supply chain. 
The rest were jobs that benefited from the sector, it stated, meaning there had been a 15% drop in the entire employment spectrum associated with the industry since 2013. 
Oil & Gas UK said it was clear further jobs were at risk, with oil costs having lost more than 50% of their value since last year leaving Brent Crude at a current price of around $49 per barrel. 
Its chief executive, Deirdre Michie, said: "This great industry of ours is facing very challenging times. 
"Last year, more was spent than was earned from production, a situation which has been exacerbated by the continued fall in commodity prices. 
"This is not sustainable and investors are hard-pressed to commit investment here because of cash constraints. 
"Exploration for new resources has fallen to its lowest level since the 1970s and with so few new projects gaining approval, capital investment is expected to drop from £14.8bn (2014) by £2-4bn in each of the next three years. 
“Difficult decisions have had to be made across the industry." 
One potential response is rival companies agreeing to pool their North Sea assets to help keep costs down and ensure the viability of the fields. 
The Times reported that senior figures from majors including BP and Shell (LSE: RDSB.L - news ) would meet Government officials on the fringes of the Offshore Europe conference in Aberdeen today for "crisis talks" and that such an arrangement was on the agenda. 
The dramatic fall in oil prices has been blamed on a glut in supply following a boom in the production of US shale oil and a lack of demand - mainly blamed on the economic slowdown affecting emerging markets, especially China. 
Oil companies have responded by cutting jobs and investment worldwide.
